newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee rebounds to end up on tender news.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee rebounds to end up on tender news.

text.p: Coffee futures rebounded from early lows to end mostly up on industry buying after a lower-than-expected tenders on the first notice/tender day for the spot November contract, traders said.
Earlier in the day, stop-loss selling drove prices to the day's low of $1,365 a tonne basis second-month January and near the immediate key $1,360 support.
Traders said a meagre of 21 lots were tendered on Friday, a level well below what some people had anticipated.
"People were expecting more tenders and there were only 21 lots and the market bounced," said one floor trader.
Traders said there could be more coffee being tendered against November in the coming weeks to reap the high November premium.
By the close, January stood $9 up at $1,394. It had earlier climbed to a high of $1,400 on the back of scale-down industry price-fixing.
Other back months also attracted light roaster industry interest.
Front-month November scooped a hefty gain of $32 on the day to close at $1,495 and widened the closely-watched Nov/Jan spread to a high of $110 from $78 at Thursday's close.
Volume on the exchange reached a modest 2,432 lots.
Traders said London's gains were also capped by New York's reluctance to push higher.
"It's at its lows at the moment. It's a bit of a struggle," said one.
On the fundamental side, traders said fresh robusta origin supplies were ample and poised to make their way to western markets soon.
"The bumper crops are coming out from everywhere. There are a lot of grading coming through...a lot of Indonesians, Ivorians, Madagascars, Ugandans," another said.
"They're all coffee that is probably going to hit the market and more is coming," he added.
Technically, analysts said coffee could test a key downside target at $1,300 in the short term with the market firmly entrenched in its current long downtrend.
"Stay short, no doubt about it," said David Charters of Investment Research of Cambridge.
